text: Dream-like tides of shadow swirl around the wet phosphorescent streetlights that glow dimly in a desolate urban intersection.  It is Fall; the misty breath of wint rises up through the sewer grates. Huddled in a small doorway is a figure swaddled in darkne We hear footsteps, expensive shoes clicking against the pavement in a brisk city gait. The figure stirs. A well dressed man passes the doorway as the figure raise its head.  It is Kuru.  Kuru is dressed in rags, his jet black skin, including his face and bald head, is covered blue tattoos.
Mister? His hand reaches for the shadows.
Mister?  You got a dollar, mister? The man ignores him as Kuru rises behind him.
Mister -- mister, please.  I'm hungry. Walking even faster, the man continues past Kuru as he strides into the street against the blinking "Don't Walk" sign.

Mister?  Mister?  Hey -- Mister! A horn explodes as a car booms past, almost hitting the m He shrieks. Kuru's laughter echoes from the dark. The man looks back but Kuru is gone.  He scurries across street toward the layered concrete parking garage. Dead red neon causes the vertical sign to read: RAGE.
The man climbs quickly, the metal stairs ringing, "thoom, thoom, thoom." As he reaches his level, a whisper floats up from the garage's concrete bowels.
... mister. The man looks over the railing but sees only shadow.  He turns and pushes through the door.

The grey garage is damp and cold, every sound echoing as though it were inside a whale. Nervous, the man hurries toward the only car on the level his red SAAB.  He digs out his keys and hits the remote a disarm. Far away, we hear a rattling metal sound. The man reaches the car groping for the door handle as th rattling draws closer. Hy jumps into the car, locking the door and jams the key the ignition. Suddenly, a baseball bat arcs down so that the twisting o the key seems to shatter the windshield.  The explosion o glass becomes --

The crash and tinkle of dirty plates being thrown into a by a busboy clearing them from the table of an old diner. Once the table is cleared by the quick automatic hands, t busboy wipes it down with a grey rag. He then places a setting.  A napkin.  A fork and a spoon. knife.  The utensils are heavy duty stainless steel.  The knife is flat like a butter knife but the end is serrated sharp enough to cut meat. We hold on the empty setting as if we were sitting at the table waiting to be served. John Bunyan throws his backpack into the booth and sits d at the empty setting.

Man, I'm starving. John is a friendly looking fellow whose simple expression awe and behind-the-times wardrobe immediately places him new to the city. The waitress steps over to the table.  John smiles.
Hi there. She stands, pencil to pad, waiting for his order.
How are you tonight? She sighs.
My feet hurt, my back is killing me and I smell like a hamburger.  Now what can I get you?
Let me see here. He runs his finger down the menu, not the items, but the prices.
I'll have the hamburger special.
To drink?
Water is fine.

Let me give you some advice, country.  When in Rome, do like the Romans, okay? She leaves. John takes out twenty dollars from a small compartment in backpack, then zips it back up. In the background, there is a commotion that swallows the normal diner noise.  John turns and we follow his gaze to far booth where a man and a woman are having an argument. Ophelia is a young, attractive woman who is uncomfortably overdressed, expecting to be in a more formal restaurant. Her date, Roman Links, has the face of a weasel.  His hai slicked back into a ponytail and he is also overdressed b quite comfortable. He holds up his hamburger to her mouth, trying to get her taste it.
No!  You know I don't eat red meat!
It ain't fucking red!  Look at it!  It's brown.  Just try it!
No! Links slaps the burger down.
Shit.  Why go out if you never try nothing?
You call this going out?
Oh, I'm sorry, this place ain't good enough for your highness. She tries to lower the argument.
I didn't mean that.
What the fuck difference does it make where you eat?  All you ever want is a fucking salad.  I take you to the fucking Ritz, you'd order a fucking salad.
You have no idea what I want. She snatches up her purse and coat.
You ain't going anywhere until you clean that plate. He snatches her by the wrist.  She struggles, then grabs fork with her free hand.
Fuck you.  Fuck your salad. She stabs him with the fork just hard enough to make him go.  Before she can get out of the booth, he catches hold her hair, yanking her head down.
You foul-mouthed bitch. He forces her face in the plate of salad and cottage chee

Now eat it.  Eat it! She screams, squirming free.  Her face covered with food, eyes burning and tearing, she runs for the nearest door, women's bathroom. Links calmly pushes the last over-sized bite of burger in his mouth.  He chews, glancing around. The diner is uncomfortably quiet. He sips the last of his coffee then politely dabs at his mouth with his napkin before getting up. Links walks to the women's bathroom and lightly knocks on door.
Fifi?  Open the door.  It's Roman.

Leave me the fuck alone. He smashes open the door, goes inside and slams it shut. John looks around the room at the frozen employees and patrons in the diner.  Muffled behind the bathroom door, sharp slap is heard and Ophelia cries out. There is another loud slap. The diner is silent, listening. John stands and slowly walks toward the bathroom as the waitress runs for the pay phone.  At the door, John can h Links talking and Ophelia crying.  He knocks. Links becomes quiet and John knocks again. The door swings open.  Links has a huge black eye.
What the fuck?
I heard the woman crying.
Are you from another planet or something?
Why don't you leave her alone? Links' bony finger pokes John in the chest.
Why don't you do what you're supposed to do and mind your own fucking business. John shrugs, staring hard.
Too late now.

You got that right. Links throws the first punch but John blocks it, ramming fist into Links' gut. Links doubles over as John grabs him, spinning him out of bathroom, cocking another punch.  He swings, mashing Link thin pointy nose, sending him sailing onto his back. Links scrambles to his feet, a wild man, hair splayed acr his bleeding face, and grabs a knife from the nearest tab Screaming, he rushes at John like an animal. John jumps back but the knife slashes open his forearm. hot blood speckles the bright white ceramic floor. John howls and lunges at Links, seizing hold of the knife hand, knocking both of them to the ground.  They thrash wildly like dogs, Links even biting John, fighting for th knife until -- Ophelia stomps on Links' arm with her high heel and snatc up the knife.
Stop it.  Stop it, Roman! Both men recoil, standing.  Links, his ears red hot, thro back his hair.
This ain't over!  This ain't over! He points at his bloody nose, staring at John.
I never forget.  This dog's got a long memory!  And you -- He stabs a finger at Ophelia who is still holding the kni over him.
Pay for your own fucking salads! They watch as he whirls, storming out of the diner.  John suddenly conscious of his bleeding arm, groans.
Oh my god.  You're really hurt.
It's okay, I think. His knees buckle a bit at the sight of so much of his own blood and he sits at one of the chrome tables.
Maybe not. Ophelia digs out a handful of paper napkins from a dispen and presses them to his wound.
I can't believe this, I mean Roman is a little crazy but what you did, it was really... thank you. John looks up into her smiling face.
You're welcome.
You're not from around here, are you?
Just off the bus, actually.  I didn't know it was that obvious. Ophelia looks up, suddenly uncomfortable that the eyes of diner have been on them the entire time.
Listen --
John.  John Bunyan. He shakes her hand, using his left.
I'm Ophelia.  We really need to get you to a doctor.
I don't really have the money.  But I'll be alright.
Do you have someplace to stay?  Relatives? He shakes his head. Ophelia looks at the clump of napkins, white soaking red.
Well, that arm is going to get infected if we don't take care of it. She thinks.
Come on.

A cab pulls up outside the Mission. The Mission is an old stone building that had once been a proud, magnificent landmark.  It is now a squatting corps with its boarded windows and crumbling brick work, it wea an edifice of dark, urban decay. John follows Ophelia from the cab into the alley that run behind the Mission.
Ophelia pounds on the heavy steel side door.
What is this place?
It used to be something like a YMCA but it was condemned.  A man named Rex Mundi somehow convinced the city to let him run a soup kitchen out of it. She pounds on the door again.
Granny?  Granny?
Your grandmother's house?
No, her name is Gretchen, but she told me to call her Granny.  She's the cook. From inside, we hear a faint, old voice.
We're closed.  Come back tomorrow.

Granny, wait.  It's Ophelia.  I have a friend here who's hurt, bleeding.  I was hoping you could... After a long pause, a series of locks and bolts click and slide before the door finally opens. Granny is a woman who looks impossibly old, thin, and wrinkled as a willow tree but has the boundless energy of child.  Her smile is a checkerboard of lost teeth gladly given for the chocolate she constantly consumes.
Granny, this is John. Her gaze fixes immediately on the cut on his arm and her bulge.
Oh, blood.  Come in.  Come in quick. She pulls them inside and the door slams shut.  We hear t locks and bolts snapping back into place.

The dining hall is a cavernous room that seems to have no walls or a ceiling, only endless rows of cheap fold out tables and chairs. Beneath nasal-humming fluorescent light, Granny sits hunc over John's arm.  Ophelia, leaning in, dabs at the wound a wet, bloody towel. Close on a large button hook as Granny pushes another sti through the flaps of skin.  She then pulls, drawing the s together. John winces.
Almost done.  There.  Just like sewing up a turkey -- She wraps it with gauze as Ophelia hands her strips of ta
Feels better already.
Just bad enough for a nice scar and a good story. She winks at him.
I don't know how to thank you.
Oh no, no -- Well -- An idea slips into her mind and a smile creeps across her face.
Okay, how about a kiss? Ophelia laughs.
Granny!
Oh, it's not like that.  Just a sweet little thank you, that's all.

Uh, sure. Granny leans forward, her eyes closed, lips puckered. John puts a hand on her shoulder, leaning in, deciding to close his own eyes.  The moment is painfully slow to arri as they inch closer and closer until finally their lips touch. Granny pops back cackling with laughter.  John laughs awkwardly as she licks her lips, tasting the kiss.
Yes, yes, very nice.  Ophelia, you ought to give them a try. Ophelia looks up at John.  There is a hint of something beyond the smile on her lips.
Now, can I get you kids something to eat, some chocolate, maybe?  Sugar for the blood?
Actually, Granny, there was something else.  I brought John here because he's new to the city and has nowhere to go. Granny is suddenly very uncomfortable.
Oh, you'd really have to ask the boss about that.
Is Rex here tonight?

At last, the fair Ophelia calls. They turn as Rex Mundi emerges from the black edges of th room. Mundi is a dark featured man, tall and sinewy who forever seems to be cast in shadow.  His clothes have an antique quality to them which includes a battered stove-pipe hat. He smiles, gliding across the room, his eyes riveted on Ophelia.
Rex, I thought you'd gone out.

You know me, Gretchen.  Always about. Mundi takes Ophelia's hand, holding it almost to his lips His face hovers over her, nostrils flaring, inhaling the scent of her soft skin.  Then, ever so delicately, he kis it.
To what do we owe this savory surprise?  Tell me, how is Ms.  Shelley?
She's good.  I'll tell her you say hello. Mundi nods.
The reason I'm here, Rex, is for my friend, John Bunyan.  He's looking for a job, a place to stay, anything. Ophelia gestures to John but Mundi does not look away fro her.
You did promise me a dishwasher, Rex. Mundi considers this, turning, appraising John.  He notic the bright, white gauze bandage and the small spot of blo seeping through.
Are we running an animal shelter now, Gretchen?  Taking in every wounded stray?
I brought him here, Rex.  It's my fault.  He was hurt because he helped me.  This is all I could think of. Mundi watches John.
The city is full of cheap hotels.
He doesn't have much money.
Then why not bring him home? Ophelia doesn't know how to answer, leaving an awkward silence.
Listen, it's okay.  I don't need any charity.
I am not offering charity.  Charity has no place here.
I thought this was a soup kitchen.
Oh it is.  But it is not run out of charity.  There is a bargain, a contract if you will.  I offer a bowl of stew in exchange for an appetite. John is confused.
This is my mission, you see.  To teach those that will listen that no one need ever be hungry. He has a voice that seems to weave the words around his audience.

Two percent of the world's population controls ninety percent of the world's wealth.  It sounds obscene, doesn't it?  Yet if you were to meet one of the two percenters you would find them quite at ease with it.  How do they do it? His black eyes flash like the spinning watch of a hypnoti

What is it that they whisper to themselves when they open a closet full of fur coats, or a garage full of sports cars?  How do they justify the consumption of so much while so many have so little?  It is painfully simple.  They may equivocate, they may obfuscate, but deep down the rich know exactly what I know.  They know that this world is cruel, it is unfair and uncaring and its single guiding principle is dog eat dog.
Gee, you're as cheery as ever, Rex.
Perhaps I should apologize for my candor.
Not necessary.
In that case, would it be a fair question to ask you what brought you to our vanity fair?
Your what?
To the big city?
Oh, just looking for a job.
Is that all?  You seek nothing but a paycheck?  You have no dreams?  No aspirations?
Well... no.  I like to cook, I hope one day to open a restaurant.
Ahh, ambition.  That is something I can understand.  Understand the dreams and you understand the man.  Would you agree with that?
Yeah, I think so.

Let me tell you, Mr. Bunyan, that I am many things to many people but I am first and always a pragmatist.  My mission is growing and Gretchen reminds me that I am in need of hands.  I can offer you the bedroom above the kitchen and all of Gretchen's stew you can eat in exchange for... your hand. John is surprised by the offer, Mundi extending his hand.
We have a deal?
We have a deal. They shake left hands. Behind them, the door to the dining room opens and clangs shut.  For a moment, silhouetted against the kitchen's li we see a very large man.
Ah, Kuru.  Come, someone for you to meet. Kuru moves into the room and when he reaches the light, w see that it is the man with the blue tattoos.
Kuru, this is John, our new hand. Kuru ignores John, whispering something in Mundi's ear.
I must be off.  Business.  Granny will show you the room, John.  Ophelia -- He tips his hat.
It is always a pleasure. Together, Kuru and Mundi leave.
I'll go find you some bedding, John.  Bye now, Ophelia.  Don't be such a stranger. Ophelia and John are alone again.
I should be going too.
Listen, do you think -- I mean, would you mind --
Would you like my phone number?
Yes.  Very much, yes. She hands him a business card she already had in her hand It reads: Slimage Surgicenter.
It's where I work.  I wrote my home number on the back.  Call me.
I will. He watches her leave then regards his increasingly throbb arm, the spot of blood growing wider.

John stands in the door frame of the small, dark room. It is bare of furniture except for a twin-sized metal fra bed and a broken chair.  A layer of dust covers the floor like moss.  A naked bulb hangs above John's head. He tugs on the pull chain but the bulb is burned out.

John throws a wall switch and a buzzing strip-light flick on.  Cancerous spots of mildew grow everywhere on the dir tub, shower curtain and tile. John urinates and flushes the toilet.  Then, leaving the light on, he edges back into his bedroom.

John sits on the bed, the metal springs shrieking beneath weight.  He takes off his shoes and lays back, pulling th single blanket over him. After a long beat, we begin to become aware of faint nois from deep within the building; pipes groaning, the distan hiss of a radiator.  It is though the building were tryin digest something. John twists, turning away from the sounds.

Crouched in the shadow behind the banister, Roman Links squats, hiding, watching Ophelia's door from the landing above.  His breathing is labored, open-mouthed as both nostrils are stuffed with wads of bloody congealing cotto Below, the lobby door opens and closes. Links presses against the spindles to watch as Ophelia cl the stairs and crosses to her apartment. Silently, he descends the stairs, creeping towards her as pulls out her keys and unlocks the door. A stair creaks. Ophelia looks back over her shoulder and sees Links.  She screams as he lunges, grabbing at her coat but she rips f of him, squeezing through her apartment door and locking behind her.
Fi!  Let me in! He pounds on the door.
What do you want?  What are you doing here?
I didn't mean to scare you, Fifi.  I'm really sorry about what happened. He leans against the door, mock pouting.
I went a little crazy, that's all.  Please, Fi, open the door.  I need you.
What happened to, "Buy your own fucking salads?"
You know I love it when you use that word.
Yeah?  Then fuck off! Ophelia feels the steel dinner knife still in her pocket.
Bitch. She rips out the knife, holding it up as if to stab him.
Don't call me that!
Fifi in heat.
You little prick.
Fifi -- Come!
Goddamn you!
Good poodle.
Stop it!
Pretty poodle. She screams, jamming the knife into the door.  An inch of blade splinters through, just missing Links' neck. Links steps back, laughing.
I'm calling the police.
I saw you leave with that guy.  I saw you take him to that flophouse.
What?  You were following me? He pulls out a small plastic folder that is labeled "Mast series 1001-2001."  Inside are five skeleton keys of whic Links draws the first.

It's killing me, Fi.  Just thinking about you and somebody else.  It's eating me up. She hears the first key go into the lock.  The lock jiggl as he twists it back and forth but it does not open. He rips the key out, pulls another and jams it in.  Ophel backs away as he works it against the lock. Another key is pushed in, its teeth fighting tumblers.  Ophelia yanks the knife out of the door.
Roman!
I need you, Fifi. He slides out the last key.
You're mine.  My Fifi. He shoves it in, the teeth sawing into the keyhole.

Roman! The lock clicks and the door floats open, stopping lightl against the chain lock.  Ophelia holds her breath. After a beat, she hears his footsteps fade down the stair Ophelia leans against the door, still clutching the knife
John sits up in his bed, hair heavy with sweat stuck to t side of his head.  Dehydration carries him to the plip, p plipping bathroom sink. As he rises, we see that his sheets are soaked with blood
John squints at his bleary eyed reflection, turns on the water, and reaches for a glass. The glass is knocked from the sink top and shatters on th floor.
Oh great -- John looks down and immediately sees why he broke the gla Where his hand had been is now a bloody, bandaged stump.
Oh god!  My -- My hand!  Where's my hand?!
His body heaving in panic, John searches frantically arou the room, under the bed, behind the radiator.
Where is it?  Oh god, not my hand.  I need that! He turns for the hall.
John finds Rex Mundi in the gleaming steel and tile kitch making himself a sandwich.
Rex! Mundi smiles warmly from behind a mountain of strange condiments, meats, and produce.
Hello, John.  Care to join me in a midnight snack? Mundi drags a serrated knife across a loaf of French brea
No, Rex.  My hand -- Look!  My hand!
Oh my, I see.
Someone -- Someone stole my hand.  I woke up and it was gone! Mundi butters the two long slices of bread with clumpy wa of mayonnaise, licking his fingers, chuckling slightly.
Relax, John, relax.  Can't you see you're only dreaming? John stares, confused.
What?  Then -- then this isn't real? Mundi begins to pile things onto his sandwich.
Real?  Oh no, John.  I didn't say that.  Dreams are more real, more true than life itself. He looks up.
They are the sum of us, John.  Secrets whispered while we slumber, revealing who we are.  And are sometimes all that we are. Mundi returns to fixing his snack.
You say you are missing something.  Your innocence?  Lost childhood, perhaps?  Any sexual shortcomings of late? He smiles at John.
Have you, maybe John, run off and sold your soul to the devil? John begins to feel a sickness in his stomach.
Perhaps, though, the answer is a more literal one. Mundi closes the top of his sandwich.
A hand which is a sandwich turns a man into a meal. He lifts the sandwich and John sees his hand between the pieces of bread.
Care for a bite? He takes a huge bite.
John's eyes crack open.  He rubs his hand, then his face.
What happened to counting sheep? He rolls over.

Close as a pile of raw liver drops into a deep metal pot sizzling with onions and yellow fat. Granny stirs the reddish brown meat into the mixture, the ladles in another cup of melted fat.  As the steam blosso up, she inhales deeply.
John, still asleep, begins to smell Granny's cooking waft up through the floorboards.  The smell is suffocating, as his mouth were suddenly stuffed with liver and onions. His eyes pop open.
Granny pours a mound of salt into her hand and begins to sprinkle it into the pot when John, stiff and disheveled, stumbles into the kitchen.
Morning.  Stomach got you up, did it? Granny scoops up a big spoonful.

Liver and onions.  Base for any good stew.  It's real revitalizing. She offers the steaming meat to him, blowing on it betwee her teeth. John swallows hard, trying to keep his stomach from turni on him.
No thanks.  Not just yet. She dumps it back into the pot.

Suit yourself. They both turn as the basement door slams open and Otto enters carrying a large sack of flour over his shoulder. Otto is the Mission's dwarf-like butcher.  He is a terrib wide man with enormous hands that he is constantly wiping his bloodstained apron.

Oh John, this is Otto.  He handles the goods and deliveries and does all of our butcher work. Otto wipes his hand before they shake. He lets the bag of flour drop to the ground and crosses b to the basement door, giving John a friendly wink.
You butcher your own meat here?
It's a lot cheaper that way. John watches as Otto shuts the basement door behind him.  After a beat, we hear the click of a lock snapping into place.
John is wandering outside the building, exploring his new surroundings.  It does not look quite as ominous in the sunlight. John turns, following a strange noise around back.
A large stray dog is chewing open some plastic garbage ba piled near a dumpster.

Hey boy.  Find anything good? As John edges closer, the dog looks up, revealing his lar canines. John freezes as the growl grows to a bark.  The dog coils ready to attack when the back door slaps open.
Hey! Otto rushes right at the dog.
Get out of here!  Go on, get! The dog whines, bolting down the alley as Otto turns to J
You alright?  Didn't bite you, did he?
No.
Yeah, mostly they're alright, even friendly considering.  But when they're hungry, you got to be careful.

Wearing heavy, yellow latex gloves, John scrubs the enorm silver pot Granny had been cooking in earlier.  There are stacks of soup bowls beside him, perhaps three hundred of them, already cleaned.  John rinses the pot and racks it. has been a long night. He opens the door and sees the bowl of stew Granny left f him.  It is still hot. John smells it.  It smells good.  He dips a finger into i and samples it.  Surprised, it tastes very good. He grabs one of the newly washed spoons.
The only lit strip of fluorescent light hangs above the f table where Granny sits, smoking a cigarette. John sits down with his bowl across from her.
All done then?
It wasn't too bad.  Those bowls were pretty clean. She smiles, nodding.
They love every last drop.
Who are they?
The poor.  Homeless.  Rex calls them the invisible people.
The same people every night?
When we started, we had thirty to forty.  Now we get two hundred. John spoons up his first taste of the stew.  Granny watch as he blows on it and slips it into his mouth.
How do you like it? He chews a juicy piece of the meat, hot in his mouth.
It's good.  It's really good. She seems as if she's about to start laughing.
What kind of meat is this?  Veal?
Whatever's donated.  Veal, chicken, beef, lamb, rabbit even. John samples it again, trying to identify the different ingredients.
Garlic, rosemary, basil.  Lots of pepper but -- He swishes the masticated stew over and around his tongue
There's something I can't put my finger on. She smiles again.
What else is in it?
Oh, a little bit of everything.
Come on, Granny.  A secret recipe?
Everyone's got a secret.
I don't have any secrets.
You do.  You just can't keep them to yourself. Granny stares off into the dark edges of the room, exhali cottony cloud of smoke.  John's chewing fills the silence He looks up.
I remember when I came to this city.  I was young and poor with little ones.
You had kids?
A long time ago, Rex helped me.  Like he helped you. She smiles her checkerboard smile. John fills his spoon with a big chunk of the stringy stew meat, but stops remembering something.
Oh, Granny, do you think you could loan me a quarter?  I'm good for it.
Ophelia, in bed, awakes and reaches to answer the ringing phone.
Hello?
Ophelia?  Hi, it's John. John leans against the wall, talking on an old rotary pay phone.
John?
Um, yeah.  We kind of met the other night... Ophelia sits up, rubbing her eyes.
Over dinner. She smiles.
Oh, hi.  How are you?  How's your arm?
It's okay.  Uh, did I wake you?  I can call another time.
No, no, it's okay.  You saved me again, actually.
Huh?
I was -- I was having the weirdest dream.
You too, huh?  I think I'm punishing myself for not getting a chance to thank you properly.
Oh really?  I think I should be thanking you. He smiles.
Okay.  Then thank me by letting me cook you dinner. She laughs.
Sounds easy enough.
Tomorrow?  Nine o'clock?
Do you mind if it's vegetarian?
How could I forget that?
Tomorrow then. He lingers, savoring her goodbye.
Bye. He hangs up, a grin spreading wide on his mouth.

We race with a pounding roar of drums, down an empty stre around a corner and into a parking lot. Faster and faster we glide across the cracked concrete wh is awash in the bright overhead kliegs toward the only ca the lot, a red Mercedes. We circle around the car, the drums at their most fevered pitch and we see the driver's door open, the window smash It hangs open, the only sound is the whining electric war that the keys have been left in the ignition.  On the car seat, we see a splintered broken gold inlay cane.

The whine becomes the metal squeak of a broken shopping c A small figure pushes the cart which is piled high with g garbage bags down a deserted sidewalk, a cigarette hangin between her wrinkled fingers. Close on the broken wheel as blood trickles from the dark load down the chrome frame.
A steady rhythm of droplets drip from the leaping faucet against the soft echoing digestive sounds from the buildi pipes.
John, unable to sleep, rolls up from his bed in frustrati

The refrigerator door opens, frigid light spilling into t dark kitchen. Inside, there is a massive bowl of raw meat.  John groans He turns, reaching for a cupboard but pauses when he noti the basement door is ajar. With one hand, he gently pushes and it creaks open.  Down uneven steps, he can make out a light at the bottom.
Otto? He steps down.
Otto, are you down here? He looks around, then starts down the stairs.

It is the old men's locker room.  Except for a sparse few hooded electrician's lamps hung from the web of pipes overhead, it is dark. John slowly moves into the labyrinth of rusting metal lockers.  The red paint, cracked and peeling, covers the locker doors like frozen flame. He creeps down the aisles past a bank of old salvaged refrigerators and freezers most of which are wrapped and padlocked with heavy iron chains.

On the pegboard, behind a six foot chopping block, John s various butchering tools; hacksaws, curved bone saws, and rows of glinting, metal cleavers and paring knives. An old white radio with a bent hanger for an antenna sits a workbench beneath the peg board, its knobs crusty with smears left by bloody fiddling fingers. A layer of sawdust covers the floor, much of it clumped together with dried blood. On a coat hook, John sees Otto's apron.
Otto? At the end of the room a dirty, clear plastic curtain han in front of what appears to be the showers. He edges toward it and slides back the curtain.  The room pitch black.

After a moment, John finds the pulls chain for the naked bulb. In the center of the room, hanging from the ceiling are several blood encrusted meathooks.  Web-like cracks have formed in the large tiles and green furry mold grows in t grout lines.  Near the door, John sees a pair of black, h rubber boots. The room reeks of rot.  John catches the odor from an old metal pail and mop in the corner of the room. Grabbing hold of the wooden handle, he lifts the mop from pail, covering his nose. There is a nasty wet, sucking noise as the tangled mop strings separate from the scum at the bottom.  In the lig he sees the mop is caked with thick, red-brown gore.
